title: Elizabeth Alexander on ‘The Trayvon Generation’
description: Alexander talks about her new book, and Lucasta Miller discusses her biography of Keats.
content: Elizabeth Alexander’s new book, “The Trayvon Generation,” grew out of a widely discussed essay of the same name that she wrote for The New Yorker in 2020. The book explores themes of race, class and justice and their intersections with art. On this week’s podcast, Alexander discusses the effects of video technology on our exposure to and understanding of violence and vulnerability, and contrasts the way her generation was brought up with the lives of younger people today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Kantor and Karen Weise
title: Amazon vs. the Union
description: The company and its new union share the same problem.
content: Last Wednesday, Derrick Palmer clocked in for his 7:15 a.m. shift at Amazon’s giant warehouse on Staten Island and spent the day packing boxes with board games, iPhones and mini vacuum cleaners. The following morning, he boarded a train to Washington, D.C., where more experienced labor leaders hailed him and his best friend, Christian Smalls, for doing what had once seemed impossible: unionizing an Amazon facility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: A reporter covering the war reflects on the legacy of the Holocaust.
description: In eastern Poland, perceptions of Russia and Ukraine are shaped by a traumatic past.
content: LUBLIN, Poland — On a recent morning, I sat in the sun-filled dining room of a tidy house in eastern Poland, across from one of the most generous men I’ve ever met.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Richmond Pollock and Kira Thurman
title: When Classical Music Was an Alibi
description: The idea that musicians and their work are apolitical flourished after World War II, in part thanks to the process of denazification.
content: On April 16, 1955, the soprano Camilla Williams became the first Black singer to appear at the Vienna State Opera, bowing as Cio-Cio-san in Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly.” Critics hailed it as a landmark and said it illustrated how much Vienna had changed since the end of World War II, a decade earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Michael F. Neidorff, 79, Dies; His Company Was an Obamacare Stalwart
description: He transformed a small company into a corporation focused on providing health insurance under government programs. It now insures 25 million people.
content: Michael F. Neidorff, who built the Centene Corporation from a small Milwaukee health plan into the nation’s largest insurer for the government’s Medicaid program and a stalwart of the Obamacare markets, died on April 7 in St. Louis. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: What Good Friday and Easter Mean for Black Americans
description: Jesus’ story does not end with his crucifixion. Similarly, racism will not have the final word.
content: I encountered my first corpse in middle school. My cousin Tammy, one of the most beautiful members of our family, died of complications from AIDS at the age of 28. The last time I saw her alive lesions covered the portions of her frail frame not draped in hospital blankets and IVs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Schreiber
title: Tom Seaver’s Statue Stands 10 Feet Tall. Just Like Seaver.
description: The Mets finally gave the ultimate honor to their franchise icon, creating a statue worthy of the Hall of Fame pitcher.
content: A statue of Tom Seaver finally made its debut at Citi Field on Friday, hours before the Mets’ 2022 home opener and years after it, arguably, might have been built.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: How ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once’ Helps to Heal Generational Trauma
description: For me, it was a scene about two rocks. For the actress Stephanie Hsu, it was taking her mom to the Los Angeles premiere.
content: When I was 13, I asked to be admitted to a psychiatric hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Christopher Coover, Auction Expert in the Printed Word, Dies at 72
description: At Christie’s, he managed sales of rare books, manuscripts and documents by the likes of da Vinci, Lincoln and Kerouac. On TV, he lent his eye to “Antiques Roadshow.”
content: Christopher Coover, who made a career out of reading other people’s mail as an expert in rare books and manuscripts at Christie’s Auction House, where he oversaw the authentication, appraisal and sale of documents ranging from the original texts of Jack Kerouac’s “On the Road” to George Washington’s annotated copy of the Constitution, died in Livingston, N.J., on April 3, his 72nd birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Z. Klein
title: Thinking About Going to the 2022 World Cup in Qatar? Here’s What to Know.
description: Tickets are on sale for the world’s most popular sporting event, but concerns over worker exploitation and laws against homosexuality have complicated the decision to attend for some fans.
content: The most avidly followed sports event on earth, the FIFA World Cup, returns this fall — another chance to find out if what’s often been said about soccer is true: That 22 men chase a ball for 90 minutes, and the Germans always win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: How to Turn Any Vegetable Into Pasta Sauce
description: With five simple techniques that pair fresh ingredients with any kind of noodle, you can create countless produce-based meals.
content: Think about all the ways tomatoes become pasta sauce — cherry tomatoes blister for a pasta salad, whole tomatoes simmer slowly into ragù. But swapping tomatoes for the springtime produce at the market or for the vegetables on their last legs in your fridge leads to so many possibilities for satisfying and exciting vegetable-focused pasta dishes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks take viewers through time loops, economic collapse and dystopian rage, with Noomi Rapace along for the journey.
content: For many fans, the girl with the dragon tattoo will always be Noomi Rapace. In the decade since she portrayed the Goth hacker Lisbeth Salander in a Swedish film trilogy, Rapace has built a thriving international career that leans heavily on thrillers and science fiction. Now, she is back in her native land with this war movie set in a dystopian future to which the conflict in Ukraine suddenly lends a tragic contemporary echo. Rapace’s Caroline Edh is a soldier so badass that she is asked to join a small unit tasked with ferrying supersecret, super important canisters — on ice skates. She agrees, but not because she is patriotic: Caroline has been told that a camp on the other side of the vast frozen expanse holds her daughter, who was abducted years earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: College Gymnastics Championships Get All-Around Lift of Lee’s Gold
description: Sunisa Lee, who won the all-around gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics last year, is competing for Auburn in the N.C.A.A. championships. Yet the field is so tough, she finished second in the collegiate all-around.
content: The N.C.A.A. women’s gymnastics championship is traditionally a gathering of outstanding gymnasts who compete a bit below world class international events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: What Britain’s Deal With Rwanda Means for the U.K. Asylum System
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a plan to send some of those seeking refuge to the central African country. What effect would the change have?
content: LONDON — The British government has announced a plan to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda, a move that prompted an immediate backlash from opposition politicians, international legal experts and human rights defenders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: ‘Call Everyone Off’: Texts to Meadows Trace Republicans’ Alarm Before Jan. 6
description: Senator Mike Lee and Representative Chip Roy, once backers of President Donald J. Trump’s claims of a stolen election, eventually urged his top aide to change course.
content: WASHINGTON — For weeks in late 2020, Senator Mike Lee, Republican of Utah, cheered on President Donald J. Trump’s effort to fight his election defeat, privately offering up “a group of ready and loyal advocates who will go to bat for him.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden’s Tax Forms Show He and the First Lady Earned $610,702 in 2021
description: The president and his wife, Dr. Jill Biden, also reported donations of $17,394 to 10 charities.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden and his wife on Friday reported earning $610,702 in 2021, almost the same amount the couple said they earned the year before, according to copies of their tax return made public by the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: What Is a ‘Poison Pill’ Defense?
description: Twitter has unveiled its plan to fight Elon Musk’s bid for the company. It’s a well-worn tactic to fend off corporate raiders and hostile takeovers.
content: On Friday, Twitter countered Elon Musk’s offer to buy the company for more than $43 billion with a corporate tool known as a poison pill, a defensive strategy familiar to boardrooms trying to fend off takeovers but less familiar to everyday investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: ‘Cyrano de Bergerac,’ Now Noseless and Drunk on Words
description: James McAvoy gives a ravishing performance, without benefit of prosthetics or props, in a new adaptation alive with the love of language.
content: “Ah, good my lords, what a nose is his! When one sees it, one is fain to cry aloud, ‘Nay! ’tis too much!’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: How Panera Bread Navigated Covid, the Labor Market, Inflation and More
description: Niren Chaudhary took over as C.E.O. just before the pandemic. He now has the company focused on climate change.
content: While Panera Bread is often situated in strip malls alongside other fast casual restaurants, the company has long been a pioneer of using quality ingredients and promoting healthy choices. It was among the first companies to add calorie counts to its menus, and it maintains a “No No List” of more than 150 substances — such as high-fructose corn syrup and aspartame — that it will not use in its recipes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: 16 Easter Brunch Recipes That Are Easy Like Sunday Morning
description: Enjoy a fabulous holiday meal without spending hours in the kitchen.
content: Brunch and Easter go hand in hand, but it’s still a weekend, and no one wants to spend all of their free time in the kitchen. Keep it simple with a wonderful meal that won’t take up too much of the day. Here are 16 easy Easter brunch recipes our readers love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: She Liked What She Saw (on His T-shirt)
description: Lindsey Ward introduced herself to Michael Richardson at a pool party in 2003, when both were about to start middle school, because she liked the band on his T-shirt.
content: One of the first things Dr. Lindsey Madison Ward noticed about Dr. Michael Taylor Richardson was his System of a Down band T-shirt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Did You Find Your Place in New York City?
description: Apartment hunting in the city has never been easy, but as the pandemic eases, the search has become seemingly impossible. If you landed a new home recently, tell us your story.
content: It’s not an easy time to find an apartment to rent in New York City.

title: Prized Russian Ship Was Hit by Missiles, U.S. Officials Say
description: The sinking of the Moskva was a major blow to the Russian fleet and the most significant combat loss for any navy in decades.
content: WASHINGTON — The Moskva was the pride of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet, a symbol of the country’s dominance of the region and a powerful war machine that had been used to launch precision cruise missiles deep inside Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Negotiate for Better Pay and Perks When the Job Offer Lands
description: With workers in high demand, the most costly mistake they can make is leaving the bargaining table without asking for more.
content: Sabrina Hill knew this email was the final straw.

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Your Covid Questions, Answered
description: Times reporters tackled reader questions about Covid and the future of the pandemic.
content: After a winter surge, infections, hospitalizations and death rates dropped steeply and, for a time, remained reassuringly flat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Wait, What if People Did Just Stay Home in Their Pajamas?
description: New neighborhood businesses far from Midtown are thriving. Maybe it’s time to redefine what “comeback” means.
content: For several weeks now, Mayor Eric Adams has been obsessively pushing a recovery agenda hinged on the return of tens of thousands of workers to offices in Midtown and Lower Manhattan. In his plan, the pandemic would be left more or less to history when the starting bell signaling the return to normalcy rings. But the surreal counterprogramming of the past few days gave us, instead, a Covid-positive mayor addressing a rattled city from quarantine after a gunman opened fire on an N train in Brooklyn during rush hour on Tuesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: You Decide Which Games Matter
description: The F.A. Cup and the Conference League have meaning not because of tradition or design, but when the players, and particularly the fans, decide they are important.
content: Only a little more than a year ago, the Europa Conference League was still just an idea. It did not, in truth, even seem like an especially good idea. Explaining where such a league would fit into the game’s pecking order, what its purpose would be, hardly had the making of a compelling elevator pitch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: ‘A Magician Up There’: How It Feels to Watch Ja Morant Fly
description: An aerial artist. A skateboarder. A BMX rider. A skydiving instructor. They all see parallels between what they do and what Morant does when he dunks in the N.B.A.
content: Sarah Bolton maneuvers in the air for a living, using silks and hammocks to defy gravity at heights of up to 25 feet. The sensation of being in the air, she said, is often one of empowerment, an extension of childhood fantasies becoming adult realities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Mike Bossy, Hall of Famer on Champion Islander Teams, Dies at 65
description: He led the N.H.L. in goals twice as his team won four consecutive Stanley Cups in the early ’80s, but he felt it never got the recognition it deserved.
content: Mike Bossy, the Hockey Hall of Fame wing who played a key role in propelling the New York Islanders to four consecutive Stanley Cup championships in the early 1980s, died on Friday at his home in Montreal. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam
title: Oh, Brother: The Not-Quite-Tell-All Books by Presidential Sisters
description: Valerie Biden Owens is one of a handful of presidential sisters who have taken the opportunity to dish on their brothers.
content: In her 1921 biography about her brother Theodore Roosevelt, Corrine Roosevelt Robinson saw no harm in sharing “almost confidential personal recollections” about the late president. “There is no sacrilege in sharing such memories, with the people who have loved him, and whom he loved so well,” she wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Gigot
title: Poems of Exile, Introspection and Self-Discovery (Cicadas, Too)
description: New collections from Akwaeke Emezi, Solmaz Sharif, Colm Toibin and Phoebe Giannisi.
content: In 39 concise, impactful poems, Akwaeke Emezi’s debut collection, CONTENT WARNING: EVERYTHING (47 pp., Copper Canyon, paperback, $16), is a triumph of selfhood that painstakingly journeys between belief and becoming. Holding tenderness and rage in one breath, the Nigerian-born nonbinary author excavates trauma, divorce and loss without restraint: “what wars have been fought on me what hauntings I carry in the blaze of/unspeakable light.” Emezi has previously written a memoir and screenplays as well as fiction, but poetry feels like a natural fit for the presumably autobiographical material in this collection, which often soothes as much as it shocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘Second Place’ and ‘Lady Bird Johnson’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: SECOND PLACE, by Rachel Cusk. (Picador, 192 pp., $17.) Cusk’s first novel since her acclaimed Outline trilogy shares similarities to her previous work — a sharply observant narrator, meditations on themes of art, beauty and the “tyranny” of parenthood — but it is also a departure. Dwight Garner, the Times critic, commented that this book has “a swirling hothouse quality that’s new” and that it “pushes its needles into the red.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisa Gabbert
title: The Shape of the Void: Toward a Definition of Poetry
description: “Poetry leaves something out,” our columnist Elisa Gabbert says. But that’s hardly the extent of it.
content: I once heard a student say poetry is language that’s “coherent enough.” I love a definition this ambiguous. It’s both helpful (there’s a limit to coherence, and the limit is aesthetic) and unhelpful (enough for what, or whom?). It reminds me of a dictionary entry for “detritus” that I copied down in a notebook: “the pieces that are left when something breaks, falls apart, is destroyed, etc.” That seemed so artfully vague to me, so uncharacteristically casual for a dictionary. It has a quality of distraction, of trailing off, of suggesting you already know what detritus means. Part of me resists the question of what poetry is, or resists the answer — you already know what it means.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Thank You for Not Killing Us’
description: An ordeal at a mental health facility in Ukraine illuminated the horrors of the Russian occupation in the areas around Kyiv.

title: Cities Try to Turn the Tide on Police Traffic Stops
description: Chiefs, prosecutors and lawmakers are rethinking the value, and the harm, of minor traffic stops like the one that ended in a man’s death in Grand Rapids.
content: Los Angeles is overhauling its traffic policing, aiming to stop pulling over cars — frequently with Black drivers — for trivial infractions like broken taillights or expired tags as a pretext to search for drugs or guns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Salman Masood and Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud
title: Days After Ouster, Imran Khan Is Back on the Trail in Pakistan
description: With fiery critiques of his rivals and the U.S., the former prime minister has drawn thousands to rallies across Pakistan and stoked fears of more political turmoil.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Tens of thousands flooded the streets across the country. Protesters brawled in a small mosque. And, at the upscale Islamabad Marriott Hotel, a fist fight broke out at an Iftar dinner between a lawmaker in Pakistan’s new government and a supporter of the recently ousted prime minister, Imran Khan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Brazil’s climate politics are shifting. That matters for the whole planet.
description: The Amazon is emerging as a central issue in this year’s presidential campaign. Leaders have taken note.
content: In Brazil, beef isn’t just food. It’s political. It’s a symbol of dignity and equality, and the price of beef is a kind of barometer of well-being in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Williams and Taylor Baucom
title: Honoring the Past by Focusing on the Future
description: Named after a team from the Negro leagues, the Nashville Stars give young players, Black and white, passion and purpose in the game.
content: NASHVILLE — It’s fitting that the Nashville Stars, a team for players ages 10 and under, are named in honor of an old Negro leagues team that played in Music City in the 1930s, ’40s, and ’50s. From the aggressive base running to the all-Black coaching staff and the speaker blaring a mix of hip-hop and R&B from the bleachers, the Stars embody the energy and excitement that made pre-integration Black baseball a cultural phenomenon as much as a sporting attraction. The team also serves as a stark contradiction of the stereotypical image of American youth baseball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Panel Presses Stephen Miller on Whether Trump Sought to Incite Crowd
description: In about eight hours of questioning, investigators pressed the former White House aide on former President Donald J. Trump’s use of “we” in his speech to supporters before the riot.
content: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol spent roughly eight hours on Thursday questioning Stephen Miller, a top White House adviser to former President Donald J. Trump, in an at times contentious exchange that included queries about Mr. Trump’s speech before a crowd the morning of the riot, according to two people familiar with the session.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Wisconsin Supreme Court Approves Republican-Drawn Legislative Maps
description: The court had approved state maps drawn by the Democratic governor, but the U.S. Supreme Court struck down that decision, citing the federal Voting Rights Act.
content: The conservative majority on the Wisconsin Supreme Court voted on Friday to adopt new state legislative maps drawn by Republicans who control the Legislature, reversing its earlier decision that favored maps drawn by the state’s Democratic governor.

title: Mayor Adams Adds More Spots in Gifted Programs
description: A hundred places for kindergartners and 1,000 for third graders will be added in an attempt to make the program more equitable.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Mayor Eric Adams plans to reboot the gifted and talented program for the city’s public schools. We’ll also look at a former New York Rangers player whose scrappiness in the courtroom brought back memories of scrappiness on the ice. And the Mets will play their home opener today.

title: Most Broadway Theaters Will Drop Vaccine Checks, but Not Mask Mandate
description: The owners and operators of the 41 theaters have decided to relax audience safety protocols that have been in place since last summer.
content: Most Broadway theaters have decided to stop checking the vaccination status of ticket holders after April 30, but all will continue to require that audience members wear masks inside theaters through at least May 31.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra Simonds
title: Moving From Elegy to Ecstasy, a Poet Pushes Against the Canon
description: In “Best Barbarian,” Roger Reeves riffs on Western tradition to challenge its omissions and expand its political and artistic possibilities.
content: Proceeding in prayerlike incantation, “Best Barbarian,” Roger Reeves’s terrific second collection, eruditely sets out to unite the Western literary canon with its omissions and oppressions. These poems resurrect an eclectic cast of characters, from Sappho to James Baldwin, to reflect on the poet’s vital yet unanswerable question: “What disaster will I deliver to my daughter?” From playful abecedarians to a psychedelic “durational” poem (which, when read aloud, is roughly the length of the Alice Coltrane song that inspired it) the reader traverses a sonic landscape from elegy to ecstasy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Kim Jong-un Gives North Korean TV Anchor a Luxury Home
description: Ri Chun-hee, who delivers the news with a soaring, bombastic tenor, received a two-story apartment in a riverside complex from the country’s leader, apparently for her loyalty.
content: SEOUL — When a brand-new luxury residential district opened in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, this week, the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, said it would be reserved for his most elite supporters, those he called “true patriots.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden Plans to Open More Public Land to Drilling
description: The president is under pressure to bring down gas prices, but any new drilling would be years away. The fees that companies pay would rise sharply.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced on Friday that it would resume selling leases for new oil and gas drilling on public lands, but would also raise the federal royalties that companies must pay to drill, the first increase in those fees in more than a century.

content: BOOK OF QUESTIONSBy Pablo NerudaIllustrated by Paloma ValdiviaTranslated by Sara Lissa Paulson

title: 27 Years in Solitary Confinement
description: The Supreme Court is to decide whether to hear the case of a Texas prisoner who says his decades in isolation amount to “cruel and unusual” punishment.
content: In the 1990s, Dennis Wayne Hope committed a series of armed robberies. After proving adept at escaping prison, he was put in isolation. He has been there for nearly three decades.

title: Late Night Isn’t Thrilled About Elon Musk’s Attempted Twitter Takeover
description: “He is super smart, definitely, but he admits that he also loves dumb jokes, so we don’t know how this could turn out,” Trevor Noah said of the Tesla C.E.O.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Russian disinformation spreads beyond its borders.
description: A New York Times’ video team traveled to the breakaway region of Transnistria to find out what residents there believe about the war in Ukraine.
content: Since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February, Moscow has ramped up its propaganda and disinformation efforts, crafting a through-the-looking-glass image of the war in which Ukraine and the West — not Russia — are to blame for Russia’s attack.

author: By Christopher Soto
title: He Never Existed. Here Are His Selected Poems.
description: In “Madness,” the poet Gabriel Ojeda-Sagué has assembled a career retrospective for a writer he invented from whole cloth.
content: In his innovative fourth poetry collection, “Madness,” Gabriel Ojeda-Sagué imagines the life and work of a fictional “minor” poet named Luis Montes-Torres, who is said to have been born in 1976 and to have died of complications from brain cancer at the age of 58, in 2035. “Madness” is presented as a retrospective volume of his selected poems, published with analysis and commentary 20 years after his death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jazmine Ulloa
title: Trump Endorses J.D. Vance in Republican Primary for Senate in Ohio
description: The move amounts to a major bet on Mr. Vance’s ability to prevail over a crowded field, and on the former president’s power to alter the course of key congressional races.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Friday endorsed the author and venture capitalist J.D. Vance in the Republican primary election for Senate in Ohio, aiming to give the candidate a needed boost in a crowded race that will test Mr. Trump’s potency as a kingmaker in key congressional contests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christiaan Mader and Rick Rojas
title: Struggling Louisiana Neighborhood Sees New Highway as a Perilous Exit
description: Residents of Lafayette are wary of a project that has dragged on for decades, but they believe that their community — where vehicles hit buildings and pedestrians — has few options.
content: LAFAYETTE, La. — These days, the McComb neighborhood of Lafayette is dotted with deserted homes, ravaged by neglect and the merciless weather of southern Louisiana. Many businesses, including the last supermarket, fled years ago, taking jobs with them. And cutting through the community is the Evangeline Thruway, a half-dozen lanes packed with cars and 18-wheelers rushing through on their way to somewhere else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Dressage Coach Acquitted of Shooting Student by Reason of Insanity
description: Michael Barisone, an Olympic equestrian coach, was found not guilty after arguing in court that he had been subjected to abuse before shooting his riding student.
content: An Olympic dressage coach accused of shooting his student was acquitted of attempted murder and found not guilty by reason of insanity in a case that stunned the elite dressage community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: War Brings New Iron Curtain Down on Russia’s Storied Ballet Stages
description: Ballet has long been a symbol of Russian culture. Now it is becoming a symbol of Russian isolation.
content: AMSTERDAM — Just days after the invasion of Ukraine, Olga Smirnova, one of Russia’s most important ballerinas, posted an emotional statement on Telegram, the messaging app. “I am against war with all the fibers of my soul,” she wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: The Case for Criticism
description: Experts say fear keeps us from sharing constructive feedback, but here’s how — and why — you should speak up anyway.
content: One thing I want to improve about myself is my ability to tell other people how to improve themselves. I am terrible at giving constructive feedback. I recently hired an administrative assistant, and I find myself far more inclined to praise her for how well she’s doing than to provide suggestions that might help her do an even better job — even though doing so would not only benefit her but also directly benefit me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Super League Bitterness, Now Playing in a New York Court
description: A lawsuit filed by an American soccer entrepreneur says the head of European soccer declared “war” on him for working with three top soccer teams.
content: It has been a year since the European Super League was born and collapsed in a two-day soccer supernova of angry statements, legal threats and bad blood. But the project’s repercussions are far from over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: illustrious
description: This word has appeared in 92 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word illustrious has appeared in 92 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 2 in “Broadway’s Cort Theater Will Have a New Name: James Earl Jones” by Michael Paulson:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: U.S. Offers Protection to People Who Fled War in Cameroon
description: Temporary protected status will allow an estimated 40,000 Cameroonians to legally live and work in the United States.
content: The Biden administration announced on Friday that it would offer temporary protected status to nationals of Cameroon, shielding them from deportation and enabling them to obtain work permits, amid escalating armed conflict that has spawned a humanitarian crisis in the African country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: How Did Quitting Your Job Change Your Life?
description: If you were part of the “great resignation,” please share your story with us.
content: The New York Times is interested in hearing stories from people who have quit their jobs during the pandemic. Did you quit your job at some point in the last two years? We’d like to talk to you!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Kathy Hochul Is Standing on a Very High Glass Cliff
description: Sex scandals, harassment, bullying, bribery. Can New York’s first female governor change the state’s political culture?
content: ALBANY — Kathy Hochul, the governor of New York, was seated at the center of an ornate dining table, nursing her throat with honey and lemon. It was late March, the height of New York’s contentious budget season, and she had been working the phones since sunrise. The governor was being pummeled in the press over proposed changes to a bail reform policy in the budget and was trying to find common ground. She’d consulted with Al Sharpton; she’d sought advice from Melinda Katz, the Queens district attorney. Twelve hours later, and with much else on her plate, she’d decided to convene a working dinner with top advisers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Jollimore
title: A Poet Who Looks at the Stuff of Daily Life and Sees Looming Apocalypse
description: Again and again in Ange Mlinko’s collection “Venice,” quotidian events generate nightmarish overtones.
content: Ange Mlinko’s poems are animated by an unusual combination of impulses. They are formal, highly polished, with hard, smooth surfaces and dense interiors, the products of intense and serious craft. But whereas formal so often suggests staid or restrained, Mlinko’s poems are anything but. They are wild, energetic, alive, wantonly catholic in their allusiveness, often downright chatty. Some have the feel of postcards, especially in their opening lines. “The hotel showers were splendidly profligate,” begins one poem in “Venice,” Mlinko’s sixth collection. The next one starts: “After the olivine waves of Marina di Torre del Lago,/we drive between colonnades of umbrella pines.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: ‘Better Call Saul’: There Will Be (Way More) Blood
description: The “Breaking Bad” prequel is back for its final season. Here’s what to remember about where we left off, as Jimmy’s transformation into Saul nears completion.
content: It’s been two years since anyone watched a new episode of “Better Call Saul,” but the characters presumably haven’t aged a minute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: John Zaritsky, Unflinching Oscar-Winning Documentarian, Dies at 78
description: He took on uncomfortable subjects like rape, cancer and assisted suicide. His account of a student’s murder on a cross-country trip won a 1983 Academy Award.
content: John Zaritsky, a documentary filmmaker known for his unflinching looks at uncomfortable subjects like rape, assisted suicide and prostate cancer and an Oscar winner for “Just Another Missing Kid,” a gripping account of a college student’s murder on a road trip, died on March 30 in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: The Wolf of Crypto
description: Jordan Belfort, the inspiration for “The Wolf of Wall Street,” is marketing himself as a cryptocurrency guru.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Pinsky
title: A Poet’s Poet: The Astonishing Career of John Keats
description: Robert Pinsky reviews Lucasta Miller’s “Keats: A Brief Life in Nine Poems and One Epitaph.”
content: Early in her book about John Keats, Lucasta Miller calls Lord Byron an “aristocratic megastar.” That funny epithet is accurate for Byron’s more-than-superstar celebrity in his day. It also suggests the many ways Byron was the opposite of Keats. Miller quotes Byron, in a letter, referring to the younger and much less well-known poet as “Jack Keats or Ketch or whatever his names are.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Tanzania’s First Female President Wants to Bring Her Nation in From the Cold
description: Samia Suluhu Hassan became the only female head of government in Africa when her predecessor suddenly died. She is setting a new course.
content: DODOMA, Tanzania — Shortly before midnight on a spring night last year, Samia Suluhu Hassan, then Tanzania’s first female vice president, appeared on television to announce to a shocked nation that the president was dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: She Wrote for the Piano’s Extremes: Bronfman on Ustvolskaya
description: Yefim Bronfman discusses Galina Ustvolskaya’s Fourth Sonata, which he will play at Carnegie Hall on Monday.
content: Galina Ustvolskaya, a reclusive composer who lived in St. Petersburg, Russia, from her birth in 1919 to her death in 2006, has acquired a reputation for works of unearthly spiritual strength and formidable technical demands. “Your fingers literally bleed,” the violinist Patricia Kopatchinskaja has said of playing them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here’s what the takeover could mean.
description: Twitter’s board is considering Elon Musk’s offer. Here are the possible next steps.
content: Now that Elon Musk, Tesla’s chief executive, has made public his bid to purchase Twitter, the next steps include board discussions on the proposal and the possibility of other people making offers. Here’s what else the takeover bid means.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ocean Vuong Brings Books to Lunch Dates, ‘Just in Case’
description: “I feel truer to myself while reading than I do experiencing the world through my body — so any chance to read is ideal for me.”
content: “A Lesson Before Dying,” by Ernest J. Gaines, “Walking in Wonder,” by John O’Donohue (in conversation with John Quinn), “A Death in the Family,” by James Agee, “Afropessimism,” by Frank B. Wilderson, “We Think the World of You,” by J.R. Ackerley, “Jane Eyre,” by Charlotte Brontë, “Hot Milk,” by Deborah Levy, “Poetics of Relation,” by Édouard Glissant, “The Sign of Jonas,” by Thomas Merton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Daniel Raymon rustles up a real challenge.
content: ACROSTIC — This puzzle, a tough example of the Puns and Anagrams genre, is by a multitalented Times constructor, Daniel Raymon, who makes cryptic crosswords and daily grids as well. If you’ve been wondering about trying cryptics, I think if you can get through this grid, you’ll be ready to try more. It’s not that “Panda” puzzles are easy, but they do follow regular crossword rules: Every square is crossed by two entries, so you have two chances to figure everything out. There are also far more anagrams, which usually help a solver out. On the other hand, the puns can be pretty wild.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Three Titles Are Just Part of the Stakes for Spence and Ugas
description: The winner of Saturday night’s bout between Errol Spence Jr. and Yordenis Ugas will have a strong claim as the best welterweight fighter and high-stakes options for his next match.
content: At first, Errol Spence ignored the dot that appeared in the peripheral vision of his left eye in August 2021. His imminent welterweight title bout against Manny Pacquiao outweighed this mysterious new problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: A Financial Services Company Illegally Leased Dogs, Massachusetts Says
description: Monterey Financial Services LLC has agreed to pay $930,000 in debt relief and restitution to settle allegations that it was conducting the practice, which is banned in the Bay State and others.
content: Shortly after Catalina Ortiz-Sierra lost her job and failed to make payments on what she thought was a loan, a collections agent in 2019 threatened to take away her dog, Milo, a Shih Tzu-poodle mix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: As G.O.P. Candidates Face Accusations, Rivals Tread Carefully
description: In several states, Republican candidates are contending with allegations of domestic violence and sexual assault. Few of their primary rivals want to talk about it.
content: WASHINGTON — When fresh allegations of domestic violence were lodged against former Missouri Gov. Eric Greitens last month, one of his Republican rivals for the state’s open Senate seat, Representative Vicky Hartzler, stepped up and called for him to end his campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Srikanth Reddy
title: Facing ‘the Can’t-See of the Future,’ in Verse and at the Chiropractor’s
description: In “Now Do You Know Where You Are,” the poet Dana Levin learns to write again and comes to terms with personal and political trauma.
content: There are two kinds of poets in the world — poets who write poetry, and poets who don’t. I fall into the second company as of late. So do many of my literary acquaintances. Mostly we write plaintive emails to each other about not writing poetry. It’s almost a genre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Why Ukraine War Crimes Trials Could Take Many Years
description: Long after the fighting ends, any prosecutions and trials arising from it could be barely beginning. Here is a look at the complexities of bringing aggressors to justice.
content: The brutalities of Russia’s war in Ukraine have stoked enormous demand among Ukrainians and much of the Western world for investigations, indictments, arrests and trials for the invaders and their commanders, notably President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. Some leaders, including President Biden, have even accused them of genocide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: For U.K. Covid Victims’ Families, Fines for Johnson Prolong Heartbreak
description: Those unable to be with dying loved ones find no satisfaction or closure with the penalty Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces for breaking lockdown rules.
content: LONDON — When Safiah Ngah’s father began coughing up blood and was rushed to the hospital from his home in central London in January 2021, she was confident that she would see him again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Obstacles to Russia’s assault on Ukraine.
content: Russia’s faltering war against Ukraine met further obstacles yesterday when the flagship of its Black Sea fleet sank after a catastrophic explosion and fire, and the E.U. moved closer to an embargo on Russian oil imports. Follow the latest updates from the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: That Letter Offering to Buy Your Stock? Think Twice.
description: Known as a “mini-tender,” the bid is usually for a price below market value. Such offers tend to fly under regulators’ radar.
content: Early this year, I opened my mail to find an intriguing offer: A company wanted to buy stock that I held.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published Poetry, From Gaza to Zoom Rooms and More
description: A selection of new poetry collections, from Mosab Abu Toha, Marlanda Dekine, Basie Allen, Shane McCrae, Ama Asantewa Diaka, Mary Jo Salter, Eloisa Amezcua and D. Nurkse.
content: THINGS YOU MAY FIND HIDDEN IN MY EAR: Poems From Gaza, by Mosab Abu Toha. (City Lights, paper, $11.17.) Written from his native Gaza, Abu Toha’s accomplished debut contrasts scenes of political violence with natural beauty: In one poem, a “nightingale departs the wet earth” two stanzas before the “sound of a drone / intrudes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kendra Hurley
title: The Smallest New Yorkers Join the Pandemic Biking Surge
description: Electric cargo bikes have become a popular way for parents to ferry their children to school and play dates, even if it means navigating city traffic.
content: When Annie Weinstock began toting her two young children to day care and playgrounds on a cargo bike three years ago, she sometimes spotted one other family in her Brooklyn neighborhood riding a similar bike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Russia’s Black Sea flagship was hit by 2 Ukrainian missiles, a U.S. official says.
description: Moscow claimed the sinking was an accident, but U.S. intelligence reports say the cruiser went down after Ukraine struck it with Neptune missiles.
content: WASHINGTON — Two Ukrainian Neptune missiles hit Russia’s flagship Moskva in the Black Sea, a senior Defense official said on Friday, providing the first American confirmation that the sinking of the Russian cruiser was the result of a Ukrainian strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Can Men Wear Leggings, Too?
description: A cyclist wonders whether his stretchy sporting gear could have a place in his everyday wardrobe.
content: There is an actual name for the particular clothing item you are talking about: meggings! It’s a neologism that would suggest that if male leggings are not yet a thing, they will be. After all, if something is present enough in our lives to merit its own term, it probably has reached, or is about to reach, critical mass.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: We begin this week’s list with a collection of short stories that is timely for the worst reasons. Yevgenia Belorusets’s “Lucky Breaks” is about poor women in Ukraine whose lives have been upended by war. The book was first published in 2018, and it’s now translated into English.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Slowing Down Sped Up Their Relationship
description: Kabir Melwani and Leah Madeline Freedland met in graduate school, but really bonded while living in his parents’ home for months during the pandemic.
content: Kabir Melwani and Leah Madeline Freedland are never at a loss for adjectives when each is asked to describe the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Burt
title: A Poet Looks at the End of the World, and Reaches for Hope
description: In “Canopy,” her seventh collection, Linda Gregerson mourns for humanity and the earth even as she clings to signs of personal connection.
content: What should we do about the end of the world? What about the end of our own lives? What should we say if we can’t do anything? Such questions have a history in poems as old as the history of poems: They animate funeral elegies, prayers to forestall the apocalypse, deathbed repentance like John Donne’s. And they have new resonance now, when climate change and global plague and general public exhaustion have put so many of us into such a rough mood, “casting about for ways to summon normal,” as the careful, careworn, learned Michigan poet Linda Gregerson says. Gregerson’s seventh collection tries patiently and concisely to support our aging bodies, our battered ecosystems and our traditions of memorable speech, along with her own Midwestern immigrant heritage with its “Scandinavian Grim.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Jerusalem Tattoo Artist Inks Pilgrims, Priests and Those Scarred by Conflict
description: For Wassim Razzouk, Holy Week is his busiest time as Christians seek a reminder of their visit to Jerusalem. But his family’s centuries-old tattoo business caters to all faiths.
content: JERUSALEM — A Jewish man who may have been drunk once asked him to tattoo “kosher” in Hebrew on his butt. His oldest customer was a woman of 101. Members of the U.S. Secret Service often stop by to sample his handiwork when they’re in town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: Reporting From Amazon’s Hometown, and Seeing the Company Everywhere
description: Karen Weise, a technology correspondent, shares how she covers Amazon and its far-reaching businesses.
content: Karen Weise is a technology correspondent based in Seattle who has covered Amazon, which is headquartered there, for The Times since 2018. With its e-commerce operation, line of web services and grocery businesses, Amazon maintains a vast reach across American society. The company has been on a hiring spree in recent years, including a large push during the pandemic, which has brought its role as a major U.S. employer into sharper focus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisy Fried
title: Best Known as a Holocaust Poet, Nelly Sachs Deserves Another Look
description: The Nobel laureate’s postwar collection “Flight and Metamorphosis,” published in 1959 and newly translated into English, reveals a poet full of mystery and depth.
content: An inviting poem is usually easy to understand; a good poem — inviting or not — usually complicates into surprise and depth. The poems in Nelly Sachs’s “Flight and Metamorphosis,” first published in German in 1959 and newly translated by the poet-critic-scholar Joshua Weiner (with Linda B. Parshall), seem little interested in invitation. But they are full of shifting surprises, mysteries and depths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Gates
title: Bill Gates: How to Develop Life-Saving Drugs Much Faster
description: We need to accelerate our work on safe medicines that help combat quick-spreading pathogens like the coronavirus.
content: The Covid-19 pandemic would look very different if scientists had been able to develop a treatment sooner. The death rates are likely to have been far lower, and it may have been harder for myths and misinformation to spread the way they did.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Love Letter: A Single Mother Meets Another Single Mother
description: Parenting alone in a pandemic isn’t for the faint of heart.
content: According to a recent Pew Research Center study, nearly a quarter of children in the United States live in single-parent homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Listfield
title: The Loneliness of the Locked-Down Single Mother
description: Having a job, a child and no help during a pandemic can take a toll — but also forge a special bond.
content: It began with a missing package. One day I got a message from a stranger on LinkedIn: “You don’t know me, but I live across the street, and I think I have your package.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Two Epic Dates and an Incredible Arcade Game Feat
description: Jennifer Banegas proposed to Alyssa Bush with a video game scoreboard and the words: “Ken Wil You Mar Me?”
content: When Alyssa Bush traveled from Baltimore to Seattle in February 2019, it was mainly to visit a friend with a new baby. But she also wanted to explore the city. With her friend preoccupied by parenthood, Ms. Bush logged into Tinder and Bumble, hoping to connect with someone she could meet for a drink or a meal. On both dating apps, she matched with Jennifer Banegas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: ‘Too smelly to sleep’: Thirteen days in a Shanghai isolation facility.
description: Hundreds of thousands of Shanghai residents have been sent to quarantine and isolation facilities. One woman described her ordeal.
content: After Leona Cheng tested positive for the coronavirus late last month, she was told to pack her bags for a hospital stay. When the ambulance came to her apartment in central Shanghai to pick her up two days later, no one said otherwise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Logan
title: One Last Book From an Outback Poet Who Was Part Hero, Part Pariah
description: Les Murray’s posthumous collection “Continuous Creation” highlights both his crankiness and the rough magnificence of the landscape he loved.
content: Born and raised in New South Wales, Australia, Les Murray was gaptoothed, pigheaded, booming, burly. (He would have said fat.) His childhood in Bunyah was not a long way from nowhere — you’d have to pass Coolongolook, Cooranbong and a lot of other one-kangaroo towns to get to Sydney, three hours away. A lover of the outback, molded but not deformed by university, he was proud of not belonging, boasting his degree the “least distinguished” ever bestowed by the University of Sydney. The best poet Australia had seen for a generation or two, by his early 30s he lived in partial exile from the literary scene. His longing for the bush grew until in his 40s he moved back to part of the old family dairy farm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Where in California Do Women Under 30 Earn More Than Men?
description: Young women are outearning young men in San Diego, Sacramento and Santa Barbara.
content: In 2000, an American woman under 30 with a full-time job earned, on average, 88 percent of what a similar man made. By 2019, young women’s pay had grown to 93 percent of men’s pay, which, while not ideal, can certainly be considered progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: He Was on His Way to Work. Then the Subway Car Filled With Smoke.
description: Houari Benkada was fasting for Ramadan and had woken up for a pre-dawn meal with his mother before setting off for work at the New Yorker Hotel. He is recovering from a gunshot wound.
content: Houari Benkada, 27, was roused from sleep at 4:30 a.m. on Tuesday for suhoor, the pre-dawn meal eaten before a day of fasting during Ramadan. He and his mother, Amina, shared Algerian borek, a savory pastry, and some dates before he went back to sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Vincler
title: Shin Gallery Charms and Surprises With a Motley Collection
description: The renegade gallerist and collector, Hong Gyu Shin, looks back on 10 years with idiosyncratic wit.
content: You may wonder whether you’ve found a curiosities shop upon entering Shin Gallery’s 10-year anniversary exhibition. The show charts the gallery’s history in the Lower East Side of Manhattan and its namesake collector’s wild but slyly judicious tendencies, with nearly 100 items filling three rooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yevgeniya Traps
title: It’s Julie Doucet’s World
description: After a two-decade break, the comic artist returns with “Time Zone J,” a graphic autopsy of youthful passion from the vantage point of a middle-aged woman.
content: The Montreal-based comics artist Julie Doucet began self-publishing her zine, Dirty Plotte, in 1987. Three years later, it became the foundation stone of the influential Canadian comics publisher Drawn & Quarterly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Biden to Nominate Michael Barr as Fed Vice Chair for Supervision
description: Mr. Barr faced pushback from progressives when his name was floated for a different position.
content: The Biden administration said on Friday that it intended to nominate Michael S. Barr, a law professor and a former Obama administration official, to be the Federal Reserve’s vice chair for supervision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: Breaking Up With Peloton
description: The stationary bike’s convenience made it a pandemic winner, but some former fans are done working out at home.
content: During the first two years of the pandemic, Kristi Falzon, who lives in Chicago, used her Peloton every day. “It was a godsend,” she said. She could exercise in her spare bedroom between Zoom meetings without worrying about other people’s germs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack and Samira Asma-Sadeque
title: Within 10 Days, Three Sikhs Were Attacked on the Same N.Y.C. Block
description: Residents are fearful in a quiet Queens neighborhood, where younger Sikhs have begun to escort their elders to the temple.
content: Gulzar Singh was walking to work on Tuesday morning, chatting with his wife on a video call, when he was attacked. Two men beat the 45-year-old Sikh across the back of the head, ripped off his turban and left him bleeding on the sidewalk in a quiet Queens neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Law That Shaped the Internet Presents a Question for Elon Musk
description: Section 230 gives companies wide latitude to host as much objectionable content as they wish.
content: “No provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Stolzberg
title: Here’s a Better Way to Care for Your Yard. Your Neighbors, and the Planet, Will Thank You.
description: Ditch the gas leaf blower and switch to an electric one. Or a rake.
content: The most recent United Nations climate report reminds us, once again, of what we already know: The steady rise in global temperature spells catastrophe. We must adapt to what cannot be undone and commit to reducing greenhouse gas emissions caused by the burning of fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: They Expected Luxury. They Got Leaky Ceilings and Broken Elevators.
description: Complaints of poor construction are on the rise in new luxury rental and condo buildings, after two chaotic years of New York real estate amid the pandemic.
content: Hero, a new 22-story condominium building in Long Island City, Queens, promised luxury: tall ceilings, high-end appliances and Spanish oak cabinetry in every apartment. Amenities would include a yoga studio, a gym, a pet spa, a roof deck “sky lounge” and a Zen garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Sienna Miller Found Catharsis in ‘Anatomy of a Scandal’
description: In the new Netflix series, the actress plays a woman whose husband’s affair gets played out in the British press. She was drawn to the echoes of her own life.
content: Two years ago, when Sienna Miller received the scripts for “Anatomy of a Scandal,” a high-gloss limited series from David E. Kelley and Melissa James Gibson, she read them straight through. “I binged them in the way that you would want to binge a six-part drama,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Cotto
title: How Rocco DiSpirito, Chef, Spends His Sundays
description: Food is the focus, from afternoons at Balthazar to cooking for his family and friends at night.
content: Rocco DiSpirito has been a fixture on the American food scene since the 1990s. He has owned a three-star restaurant, been a reality television star and written over a dozen cookbooks, which range in theme from Italian American to “comfort keto.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Ann Hutchinson Guest, Who Fixed Dance on Paper, Dies at 103
description: She was a leading advocate of and expert on dance notation, helping to do for choreographed works what a score does for music.
content: Ann Hutchinson Guest, one of the world’s foremost authorities on dance notation, the crucial practice of recording dances on paper in the manner of a musical score, died on April 9 at her home in London. She was 103.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Clark
title: In Edna St. Vincent Millay’s Diaries, the Private Life of a Celebrity Poet
description: Seven decades after Millay’s death, “Rapture and Melancholy” paints a picture of artistic triumph, romantic tumult and a daily life that descended into addiction.
content: Edna St. Vincent Millay (1892-1950) was once the most famous poet in America. Her collections sold tens of thousands of copies, and her readings filled theaters from New York to Texas. She was the female voice of the Jazz Age, the New Woman incarnate whose passionate and iconoclastic verse earned her a devoted following. Her 1920 poem “First Fig” became an anthem for a generation tired of Victorian mores:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: The Horrors of Russian Occupation
description: Disturbing stories are emerging of the terror inflicted on Ukrainian civilians.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Clifford Krauss
title: Fuel Prices Send Airfares Higher, but Travelers Seem Ready to Pay
description: Supplies are not keeping up with demand, and costs may go higher, experts say.
content: A stunning rise in the cost of jet fuel has sent airfares soaring, and industry experts say they are likely to go higher. For now, though, travel-starved consumers seem more than willing to pay up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurence H. Tribe and Jeremy Lewin
title: $100 Billion. Russia’s Treasure in the U.S. Should Be Turned Against Putin.
description: It’s the only way to signal that the United States is committed to making even the world’s most powerful states pay for their war crimes.
content: As Vladimir Putin vows to continue his genocidal invasion of Ukraine, investigators at the Treasury Department and Justice Department are scrambling to seize Russian yachts, mansions and the other spoils of his despotic regime. Meanwhile, in Washington, Representatives Tom Malinowski of New Jersey and Joe Wilson of South Carolina have advanced a bipartisan measure to clarify exactly how much power the executive branch has to liquidate those assets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Bonding Over Faith and Football
description: Janice Matamoros and Rayburn Ewers, both octogenarians, met after moving to a senior living community in Texas.
content: Janice Matamoros and Rayburn Ewers, who goes by Otto, each prayed a lot before moving to the Belmont Village Senior Living community in Lakeway, Texas, in 2019. Though both of their prayers were answered, hers came with a bit of a twist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Leeks and Fish Get a Lift From a Tangy Salsa Verde
description: In this weeknight-friendly dinner, a bright, bold briny sauce, built on Castelvetrano olives, works its magic on two normally mild ingredients.
content: I never appreciated leeks as a vegetable — as opposed to an aromatic — until I ate them with vinaigrette in Paris on my college year abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Woman Dies After Trying to Scale Border Fence Into Arizona
description: The woman, who was using a climbing harness, became “ensnared” on the border fence just west of Douglas, Ariz. Officials said she was trapped upside down for a “significant amount of time.”
content: Officials are investigating the death of a woman who became stuck upside down as she tried to cross into the United States from Mexico over a 30-foot-high steel border fence in southeastern Arizona on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times
